summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against Honeywell International, Inc. ("Honeywell"), a New Jersey-based company that manufactures and sells automotive and aerospace products.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Newark, New Jersey, Honeywell and its predecessor, Aetna Casualty & Surety Company (Aetna), were charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder. The complaint alleges that, in violation of the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, the defendants were not required to participate in the allocation of liability for claims arising from exposure to asbestos-related products. In addition, the complaint further alleges that the defendants failed to adequately account for the fact that they were not entitled to insurance coverage for products that were not covered by the insurance policies.  The SEC alleges that Honeywell violated Section 5 of the Exchange Act by failing to comply with certain of the recommendations in its complaint.  In its judgment, the court found that, as a matter of principle, that the allocation methodology violated Section 15(a) of Exchange Act Rule 15b2-1, and that it violated Rule 15a-2-2 thereunder, as well as Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of Investment Advisers Act of 1940 ("Advisers Act").  The court also ruled that, for the purpose of determining whether to grant partial summary judgment to Honeywell, it had to determine whether to adopt the "time-on-the-risk" allocation methodology.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the Court also ordered the defendants to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest and a civil penalty equal to the amount of their profits.  On the same day, the SEC filed a complaint in federal district court in New Jersey charging Honeywell with violating Exchange Act Rules 15b-20, 13a-21, and 13b-24, and with aiding and abetting violations of Section 17(a)(1) of The Exchange Act and Rules 17a-3, 13b1-1 thereunder and the related allocation methodology under Section 206(3).  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New Jersey today announced that it filed a parallel criminal case against Bendix in which Bendix pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud and was sentenced to 10 years imprisonment and ordered to pay a $1 million civil penalty.
